text: saying goodbye to a national treasure
people from all walks of life took to
the streets in shock anger and grief to
mourn one of Pakistan's most famous
singers I'm Jud Sabri came from a long
line of Kavala singers of devotional
music from the Sufi tradition an Islamic
practice opposed by religious extremists
who see it as heretical his father and
uncle were legends of the artform
enjoyed by millions of people here but
it was um Jed who made the music more
accessible to the year he was on his way
to a studio for a special transmission
for the holy month of Ramadan when he
was shot by two gunmen on a motorcycle
he had finished a performance on a
television program earlier that morning
his last Cavalli song a group linked to
the Pakistani Taliban claimed
responsibility for the attack saying
they killed the singer for blasphemy the
killing of M jet Sabri brought to the
surface a lot of anger and frustration
both of the government and the security
forces people here say that after every
major attack the authorities vow the
same thing time and time again to ramp
up security and go after those
responsible officials say that the
intense security operations in Karachi
and elsewhere in the country have made a
difference and pushed back militants but
for many the violence still continues on
the ground as Pakistan bids farewell to
one of its most loved celebrities many
questions will be asked about why he had
to go that way and what could have been
done to stop this brutal attack China
Halil BBC News Islamabad
